title: Jealous of Duolingo’s Social Media? The Strategist Behind It Just Shared Advice for Brands
description: Zaria Parvez, the social media manager behind the infamous green owl, explains what it takes to craft an enviable social-first brand.
content:
At some point, many founders have probably said to their teams, “We need to be more like Duolingo.“ Over the past five years, the language education app has become the it brand on social media. The company’s green owl mascot became one of the internet’s main characters, reaching another stratosphere of cultural ubiquity as it starred in increasingly comical, even bizarre, videos. The content had little—if anything—to do with Duolingo’s actual business of encouraging people to learn a foreign language, but struck a chord, becoming the model for a whole new school of thought: unhinged marketing.

That strategy all came from a single employee: Zaria Parvez. After graduating from college in 2020, Parvez joined Duolingo as its sole social media manager and remained a one-woman team until last year. Parvez, who publicly revealed herself as the social mind behind the owl a year into the schtick, announced on LinkedIn earlier this week that she was leaving Duolingo, just after the company reported 41 percent revenue growth and record profits in the second quarter. During her tenure, the company’s footprint grew from 300,000 Instagram followers to 4.6 million. Twitter went from 370,000 followers to 1 million. Perhaps most impressive and enviable, the brand’s TikTok catapulted from a mere 35,000 followers to 16.7 million, a growth rate of more than 45,600 percent. Business leaders admire those results, but getting there requires ample strategy. “Wanting to be like Duolingo is meaningless if you don’t have a destination,” Parvez told social media strategist Rachel Karten, who writes the popular social media and marketing strategy newsletter, Link In Bio. “If you don’t know where you’re going, distractions will look like opportunities.”

Parvez told Karten that with so much brand saturation on consumers’ social feeds, investing in a TikTok presence or commenting on posts in character is no longer enough to stand out. To emulate Duolingo’s success, Parvez said companies should worry less about creating their own mascot or copying other brands and focus on the process behind the content. That means speeding up approvals, empowering social teams to take creative control, and normalizing failure, knowing that some ideas and posts will inevitably fall flat. People assume the Duolingo strategy came from an “insane strategy deck” Parez said, but really, it was just her asking her bosses: Can I try this? “There’s just no shortcut,” she told Karten. “If you start trying to be like every other brand, at some point, you’re just no, because-ing, instead of yes, and-ing.”



If brands want to embrace that spirit of experimentation, Parvez recommended companies invest in “slow burn” content that is less concerned with algorithms and virality and more about building a sustained community through storytelling and serialized posts, which keep users coming back, such as “Roomies,” the short-form show that the rewards and loyalty platform Bilt produced. “There’s really something powerful about reclaiming that ritual,” said Parvez. “The next big brand will be the one that unlocks that.”

Above all, Parvez warned brands: “Do not use social as a crutch.” Instead, chief marketing officers need to remember: “Your community is your insurance policy, so invest in them. Curate them. Take care of them, because you don’t know when you’ll need them.”
summary: Zaria Parvez, the social media manager behind Duolingo, has shared her advice for brands to emulate the company's success in social media. She advised companies to focus less on creating their own mascot or copying other brands and instead on the process behind the content. Parvez also suggested that companies should invest in "slow burn" content that is less concerned with algorithms and virality, and more about building a sustained community through storytelling and serialized posts. She also warned against using social media as a crutch, and instead of relying on it, she suggested that brands should consider investing in their communities as their insurance policy.
shortSummary: Despite Duolingo’s success on social media, companies must adopt a more targeted strategy focusing on engaging, community-driven content, emphasizing long-term strategic thinking rather than just copying others.

I’m leaving Duolingo. After five unforgettable years, 8 billion impressions and even more jaw-drops - it's time to take off the suit. Fresh out of college in 2020, I led Duolingo’s evolution into a social-first brand, turning organic social into a growth engine that drove waves of new users. Duolingo's social helped catapult the company’s market cap to nearly 7× in just five years by breaking into culture as an unexpected disruptor. It's been a privilege working alongside a phenomenal team that lifted me up and made the impossible feel routine. You all taught me how to fly & own my power every single day. As for the what, why, who, when, and how…I’m saving all that for the book. 😉 So yes, I’m no longer Zaria from Duolingo. I’ll mourn that for a while. For now, I’m just Zaria. But, then again, maybe there's nothing “just” about it. Hi! I’m Rachel Karten, a social media consultant based in Los Angeles. I have worked in social media for over ten years and previously led the social media team at Bon Appétit and Epicurious. During my four years at Bon Appétit, the social team won a social Webby Award and a prestigious National Magazine Award for best social. Since leaving in 2020, I have been consulted on social media strategies for brands like CAVA, Google, and more.
Link in Bio is one of the top business newsletters on Substack has been featured in the Wall Street Journal, Grub Street, Slate, CNBC, and more.
WHAT IS LINK IN BIO?
Through thoughtful interviews with the social managers behind your favorite brands and insightful breakdowns of strategies—an essential tool for anyone interested in social media and the internet.
WHAT DO YOU WRITE ABOUT?
Link in Bio is anchored by free weekly interviews with the people who actually press post. We’ve heard from author Seth Godin, Nicolle Lopez who wrote that Amtrak “trains” tweet, and Moh Kloub who creates shareable content over at ESPN.
In addition to these interviews, paying subscribers get a weekly strategy send—a jam-packed newsletter with ideas on what to post, short essays on trends I’m noticing, and lots of tips for navigating this world of brand social. Here’s an example of what a strategy post looks like.
I also send quarterly trend reports to paid subscribers. They are like getting early access to what you’ll end up seeing on your feed in six months. You can find an example of one here.
Most exciting, all paying subscribers will get an invitation to the Link in Bio Discord! This is a place for social professionals to meet, bounce ideas off one another, chat with newsletter interviewees, get feedback in real time, and more. I’m in there every day—sharing posts I love and answering questions.

argos_summary: Zaria Parvez, Duolingo’s former sole social‑media manager, drove the brand’s explosive growth from 300,000 to 4.6 million Instagram followers and 16.7 million TikTok followers, turning the company into a cultural icon through unhinged, character‑driven content. Her departure follows a record‑breaking quarter of 41 % revenue growth and highlights her belief that brands should focus on rapid approval, creative autonomy, and a willingness to fail rather than copying mascots. Parvez advises companies to invest in slow‑burn, serialized storytelling that builds lasting communities, and warns that social media should not replace genuine community engagement. The article also includes a heartfelt LinkedIn farewell, fan tributes, and a brief overview of the Link In Bio newsletter that interviews social media leaders and offers strategy insights.
